questions.text: 14 yr Male was brought by his mother to the OPD. She says that for the past few months, she has been getting repeated complaints from the school regarding the decline in academic performance and recurrent episodes of giving blank looks to the teachers in class. The child says he often gets abdominal pain and strange burning rope-like smell just prior to the episode. The mother says she has witnessed similar episodes at home too. During episodes, she says the child makes strange lip movements, and following episodes the child often remains confused for a while. The most likely diagnosis, in this case, would be
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Complex partial seizures As The child has a recurrent blank, vacant expression with rope-like smell(olfactory hallucination ), strange lip movement(Automatism), and post-ictal confusion all point towards the diagnosis of Complex partial seizures/Focal unaware seizure.

questions.text: Consider the following points regarding guidelines for starting AED therapy Start with one first-line drug Always start with the maximum dose and gradually decrease as per side effects If the first-line drug fails start with the second-line drug in combination with the preferred first line at the maximum tolerated dose A minimum number of drugs in combination to be used at any one time BD /TDS preferred over OD dosing Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1,4 are true Statement 1,4 is true about guidelines for starting AED therapy. Other corrected statements- Start at a low dose; gradually increase the dose until effective control of seizures is achieved or side effects develop If the 1st drug fails, start the 2nd first line followed by the gradual withdrawal of the first drug if possible. OD preferred over BD /TDS dosing

Highyeild:

Guidelines of anticonvulsant therapy- Start with one first-line drug Start at a low dose; gradually increase the dose until effective control of seizures is achieved or side-effects develop (drug levels may be helpful ) Optimize compliance (use a minimum number of doses per day ) If the 1st drug fails (seizures continue or side-effects develop), start the 2nd first line followed by the gradual withdrawal of the first drug if possible. If 2nd drug fails (seizures continue or side effects develop), start a second -line drug in combination with the preferred first-line drug at the maximum tolerated dose. If the combination fails, replace 2nd line with an alternate 2nd line drug If the new combination fails, check compliance and reconsider diagnosis (Are events seizures? Occult lesion? alcohol/drugs confounding response?) Consider the alternative, non-drug treatments (e.g. epilepsy surgery, vagal nerve stimulation) Use a minimum number of drugs in combination at any one time

questions.text: 18 yr old Male was brought to the casualty by his friends when this morning they noticed tremors in his right upper limb. Initially, tremors started in the right index finger followed by the involvement of other fingers then the wrist, elbow, and finally the whole right arm. This was followed by weakness of the right upper limb. The phenomenon experienced by this patient is?

options.label: A
options.text: Focal seizures with loss of consciousness

options.label: C
options.text: Focal seizures with intact consciousness with Todd's paralysis

options.label: D
options.text: Jacksonian March followed by Todd's paralysis

questions.correct_answer: D. Jacksonian March followed by Todd's paralysis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Jacksonian March followed by Todd's paralysis The clinical vignette points to focal seizures with intact consciousness. However, the question asked is a phenomenon . Thus the answer becomes Jacksonian March(Abnormal motor movements may begin in a very restricted region, such as the fingers , and gradually progress to include a larger portion of the extremity ) followed by Todd's paralysis ( A localized paresis for minutes to many hours in the involved region following the seizure).

Highyeild:

Focal seizures with intact consciousness Clinical feature- motor manifestations tonic, clonic, or myoclonic movements nonmotor manifestations sensory, autonomic, or emotional symptoms No impairment of awareness. Jacksonian march- The abnormal motor movements may begin in a very restricted region, such as the fingers , and gradually progress (over seconds to minutes) to include a larger portion of the extremity. representing the spread of seizure activity over a progressively larger region of the motor cortex. Todd’s paralysis - A localized paresis for minutes to many hours in the involved region following the seizure. Epilepsia partialis continua- Seizure may continue for hours or days.(Rare) refractory to medical therapy. changes in somatic sensation (e.g., paresthesias ) vision ( flashing lights or formed hallucinations) Equilibrium (sensation of falling or vertigo) Autonomic function (flushing, sweating, piloerection) Focal seizures arising from the temporal or frontal cortex alterations in hearing, olfaction, or emotional state. the sensation of unusual, intense odors (e.g., burning rubber or kerosene) or sounds (crude or highly complex sounds), or an epigastric sensation that rises from the stomach or chest to the head . Some patients describe odd, internal feelings such as fear, a sense of impending change, detachment, depersonalization, déjá vu, or illusions that objects are growing smaller (micropsia) or larger (macropsia). These subjective, “internal” events that are not directly observable by someone else are referred to as auras.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Focal seizures with loss of consciousness- It does not show the Jacksonian march phenomenon and Todd’s paralysis. Option: B, C & D is the better answer.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman is evaluated for seizure-like episodes. She has a history of major depressive disorder and bipolar personality disorder. You are called to the bedside during an episode. You observed her head turning vigorously from side to side, twitching of all 4 extremities without loss of consciousness, and upward thrusting of the pelvis. Along with the Clinical presentation, which of the following findings could assist you in the diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: EEG monitoring during the episode shows spike and wave pattern

options.label: B
options.text: EEG monitoring during the episode shows polyspike discharge

options.label: C
options.text: A normal creatine kinase within 30 mins of episode

options.label: D
options.text: A normal prolactin level within 30 mins of episode

questions.correct_answer: D. A normal prolactin level within 30 mins of episode
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A normal prolactin level within 30 mins of episode Certain behaviors of this patient such as side-to-side turning of the head, twitching of all four extremities without loss of consciousness, and pelvic thrusting are more commonly associated with psychogenic rather than epileptic seizures. Measurement of prolactin levels helps to distinguish generalized and some focal seizures from psychogenic seizures because prolactin levels rise in these disorders but remain normal in psychogenic seizures.

Highyeild:

Psychogenic seizures - Nonepileptic behaviors that resemble seizures and maybe conversion reactions that occur under psychological seizures. Certain behaviors such as side-to-side turning of the head , ictal eye closure, asymmetric and large-amplitude shaking movements of the limbs , twitching of all four extremities without loss of consciousness , and pelvic thrusting are more commonly associated with psychogenic rather than epileptic seizures . Psychogenic seizures often last longer than epileptic seizures and may wax and wane over minutes to hours . EEG may be normal in Psychogenic/Focal seizures . polyspike patterns are seen in episodes of GTCS . Measurement of serum prolactin levels may also help to distinguish between epileptic and psychogenic seizures. Most generalized seizures and some focal seizures are accompanied by a rise in serum prolactin during the immediate 30-min postictal period , whereas psychogenic seizures are not, though this is not always reliable because baseline prolactin levels are rarely available and certain medications can elevate prolactin levels. The diagnosis of psychogenic seizures also does not exclude a concurrent diagnosis of epilepsy, because the two may coexist.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A.EEG with spike and dome pattern are seen in Absent seizure. Option: B.EEG with polyspike patterns is seen in episodes of GTCS . Option: C.Serum creatine kinase may rise following a seizure , but this is not sensitive for detection of seizure.

Solution:

Cerebral contusion A patient with a cerebral contusion has a 5–25% risk of epilepsy.
